Collect the data stored across individual HDF5 files, fuse them and store them in a single, separate HDF5 file.

Parameters:batch (dict) – job description

Create job descriptions for parallel computing.

Parameters:**kwargs –

no additional input arguments required
Returns:job descriptions
Return type:Dict[str, List[dict] or dict]
data_dir¶
Returns:absolute path to the directory with the .data HDF5 files, containing output data of all modules
Return type:str

Note

Creates the directory if it doesn’t exist.

figures_dir¶
Returns:absolute path to folder containing .figure files, containing the figure output of each module
Return type:str

Note

Creates the directory if it doesn’t exist.

Returns:absolute path to the directory with the .data HDF5 files, containing output data of all modules
Return type:str

Note

Creates the directory if it doesn’t exist.

Returns:absolute path to the .pipe YAML pipeline descriptor file
Return type:str

Returns:pipeline built in modular form based on pipe and handles descriptions
Return type:List[JtModule]
Raises:PipelineDescriptionError – when information in pipe description is missing or incorrect

Returns:jterator project object
Return type:JtProject
project_dir¶
Returns:directory where joblist file, pipeline and module descriptor files, log output, figures and data will be stored
Return type:str
remove_previous_output()[source]¶

Remove all figure and module log files.

Note

These files are only produced in the first place when headless is set to False.

run_job(batch)[source]¶

Run pipeline, i.e. execute each module in the order defined by the pipeline description.

Parameters:batch (dict) – description of the run job
start_engines()[source]¶

Start engines for non-Python modules in the pipeline. We want to do this only once, because they may have long startup times, which would slow down the execution of the pipeline, if we would have to do it repeatedly for each module.

Note

For Matlab, you need to set the MATLABPATH environment variable in order to add module dependencies to the Matlab path.

tmlib.jterator.module module¶

class tmlib.jterator.module.CaptureOutput[source]¶

Bases: dict

Class for capturing standard output and error of function calls.

Usage:

with CaptureOutput() as output:
    my_function(arg)

This redirects the STDOUT and STDERR string and stores it in a dictionary.

class tmlib.jterator.module.ImageProcessingModule(name, module_file, handles_description)[source]¶

Bases: object

Class for a Jterator module, the building block of a Jterator pipeline.

build_error_message(input_data, stdout, stderr, message='')[source]¶

Build a custom error massage that provides the standard input as well as standard output and error for an executed module.

  • stdout (str) – standard output of the module execution
  • stderr (str) – standard error of the module execution

language¶
Returns:language of the module
Return type:str
prepare_inputs(layers, upstream_output, data_file, figure_file, job_id, experiment_dir, headless)[source]¶

Prepare input data that will be parsed to the module.

Parameters:
  • layers (Dict[str, dict]) – name of each layer and the corresponding image object
  • upstream_output (dict) – output data generated by modules upstream in the pipeline
  • data_file (str) – absolute path to the data file
  • figure_file (str) – absolute path to the figure file
  • job_id (str) – one-based job identifier number
  • experiment_dir (str) – path to experiment directory
  • headless (bool) – whether plotting should be disabled

Note

Images are automatically aligned on the fly.

Warning

Be careful when activating plotting because plots are saved as html files on disk. Their generation requires memory and computation time and they occupy quite some disk space.

Returns:keys: name of the input argument, values: input data
Return type:dict
run(inputs, engine=None)[source]¶

Execute a module, i.e. evaluate the corresponding function with the parsed input arguments as described by the handles.

Output has the format:

{
    'data': dict,
    'stdout': str,
    'stderr': str,
    'success': bool,
    'error_message': str
}
Returns:output
Return type:dict
write_output_and_errors(stdout_file, stdout_data, stderr_file, stderr_data)[source]¶

Write standard output and error to log file.

Parameters:
  • stdout_data (str) – standard output of the module execution
  • stderr_data (str) – standard error of the module execution

tmlib.jterator.project module¶

class tmlib.jterator.project.JtAvailableModules(repo_dir)[source]¶

Bases: object

A class for holding information about available Jterator modules in the JtLibrary repository.

MODULE_FILE_EXT = set(['jl', 'r', 'R', 'py', 'm'])¶
static get_modules(lib_dir)[source]¶

Return a Jtmodule object for all available .handles files in the repository.

handles¶

Handles files are assumed to reside in a subfolder called “handles” and have the suffix ”.handles”.

Returns:handles name and description
Return type:dict

See also

create_handles

module_files¶

Module files are assumed to reside in a subfolder called “modules” and have one the following suffixes: ”.py”, ”.m”, ”.jl”, ”.r” or ”.R”.

Returns:paths to the module files
Return type:List[str]
module_names¶

Module names are the basenames of the module_files without the suffix.

Returns:names of the modules
Return type:List[str]
pipe_registration¶

Build pipeline elements for registration in the UI in the format excepted in the “pipeline” section in the .pipe file.

Returns:pipeline elements
Return type:List[dict]
serialize()[source]¶

Provide information in the format required by server:

{
    "modules": list,
    "registration": list,
}
Returns:
Return type:dict
class tmlib.jterator.project.JtProject(project_dir, pipe_name, pipe=None, handles=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

A class for a Jterator project.

A Jterator project is defined as a folder containing a .pipe file. The class holds information about the project, in particular on the content of YAML pipeline and module descriptor files that can be edited in the JtUI app.

create(repo_dir=None, skel_dir=None)[source]¶

Create a Jterator project: Create the project folder and an empty “handles” subfolder as well as a skeleton .pipe file, i.e. a pipeline descriptor file with all required main keys but an empty module list. When skel_dir is provided, the .pipe and .handles files are copied.

Parameters:
  • repo_dir (str, optional) – path to repository directory where module files are located
  • skel_dir (str, optional) – path to repository directory that represents a project skeleton, i.e. contains a .pipe and one or more .handles files in a handles directory.
experiment¶
Returns:name of the corresponding experiment
Return type:str
handles¶
Returns:name and description of modules
Return type:List[dict]
pipe¶
Returns:name and description of the pipeline
Return type:dict
remove()[source]¶

Remove a Jterator project, i.e. kill the folder on disk.

save()[source]¶

Save Jterator project: Update the content of .pipe and .handles files on disk according to modifications to the pipeline and module descriptions.

serialize()[source]¶

Serialize the attributes of the class in the format:

{
    "experiment_name": str,
    "project_name": str,
    "pipe": {
        "name": str,
        "description": dict
    }
    "handles": [
        {
            "name": str,
            "description": dict
        },
        ...
    ]
}
Returns:
Return type:dict
tmlib.jterator.project.list_jtprojects(directory)[source]¶

List Jterator projects in a given directory. A Jterator project is defined as a folder containing a .pipe file.

Parameters:directory (str) – absolute path to a directory
